sections.heading: What This Calculates
sections.content: This tells you how many calories (energy from food) your body needs each day to stay healthy and active.

sections.heading: The Formula (Mifflin-St Jeor Equation)
sections.formula:
For Boys/Men: BMR = (10 × weight in kg) + (6.25 × height in cm) - (5 × age) + 5
For Girls/Women: BMR = (10 × weight in kg) + (6.25 × height in cm) - (5 × age) - 161

sections.heading: Step-by-Step on Paper
steps: Write down your weight in kilograms (kg). If you know pounds, divide by 2.2
Write down your height in centimeters (cm). If you know inches, multiply by 2.54
Multiply your weight by 10
Multiply your height by 6.25
Multiply your age by 5
Add step 3 + step 4
Subtract step 5 from that total
Add 5 if male, subtract 161 if female. This is your BMR!
Multiply BMR by activity level (1.2 for sitting, 1.55 for moderate activity, 1.9 for hard work)

sections.heading: What This Calculates
sections.content: This helps you figure out how much food you need to store for your family for a certain number of days.

sections.heading: The Formula
sections.formula: Total Calories Needed = People × Days × Calories per Person per Day

sections.heading: Step-by-Step on Paper
steps: Count how many people need food
Decide how many days you want to plan for
Pick calories per person (usually 2000 for normal, 1500 for survival)
Multiply: People × Days × Calories
To find pounds of food: divide total calories by 1500 (average calories per pound of dried food)

example.title: 4 people for 30 days at 2000 calories each:
example.steps:
4 × 30 × 2000 = 240,000 total calories
240,000 ÷ 1500 = 160 pounds of food needed

sections.heading: What This Calculates
sections.content: If you know how many calories of food you have stored, this tells you how many days it will last your family.

sections.heading: The Formula
sections.formula: Days of Food = Total Calories ÷ (People × Daily Calories per Person)

sections.heading: Step-by-Step on Paper
steps: Add up all the calories in your food storage
Count how many people will eat the food
Decide daily calories per person (usually 2000)
Multiply people × daily calories to get 'daily need'
Divide total calories by daily need = days of food

example.title: 500,000 calories stored, 4 people eating 2000 cal/day:
example.steps:
Daily need = 4 × 2000 = 8000 calories per day
500,000 ÷ 8000 = 62.5 days of food

daily-water-needs.title: How Much Water Do You Need?

sections.heading: What This Calculates
sections.content: This tells you how many gallons of water your group needs to survive, based on climate and activity.

sections.heading: The Formula
sections.formula: Daily Water = People × Gallons per Person × Climate Multiplier

sections.heading: Step-by-Step on Paper
steps: Count number of people
Start with 1 gallon per person per day (minimum)
If hot weather, multiply by 1.5
If doing hard work, multiply by 2
Add 0.5 gallons per person for cooking
Multiply by number of days to store

sections.heading: Tip
sections.tip: A gallon is about 4 liters. You can measure with any container - 4 large water bottles = 1 gallon!

chlorine-purification.title: How to Purify Water with Chlorine/Bleach

sections.heading: What This Calculates
sections.content: This tells you exactly how much household bleach (sodium hypochlorite) to add to water to kill germs and make it safe to drink.

sections.heading: The Formula
sections.formula:
Drops of Bleach = Gallons of Water × 8 (for regular 5-6% bleach)
Or: 2 drops per liter / 8 drops per gallon

sections.heading: Step-by-Step on Paper
steps: Check your bleach - it should be plain, unscented, 5-6% sodium hypochlorite
Measure your water in gallons or liters
For each gallon: add 8 drops of bleach
For each liter: add 2 drops of bleach
If water is cloudy or very cold, double the amount
Stir well and let stand 30 minutes before drinking
Water should have slight chlorine smell - if not, add more and wait

example.title: 5 gallons of clear water with 6% bleach:
example.steps:
5 gallons × 8 drops = 40 drops
Using a dropper: 40 drops (about 2ml)
Wait 30 minutes, then safe to drink!

sections.heading: Tip
sections.tip: 20 drops = about 1ml. A teaspoon is about 100 drops. If bleach is old or weak, double the amount and wait longer.

rainwater-collection.title: How Much Rainwater Can You Collect?

sections.heading: What This Calculates
sections.content: This tells you how many gallons of water you can collect from your roof when it rains.

sections.heading: The Formula
sections.formula:
Gallons = Roof Area (sq ft) × Rainfall (inches) × 0.623
Or: Liters = Roof Area (sq m) × Rainfall (mm)

sections.heading: Step-by-Step on Paper
steps: Measure your roof length and width in feet
Multiply length × width = square feet
Check weather for expected rainfall in inches
Multiply: sq ft × inches × 0.623
Reduce by 20% for losses (splashing, first flush)
This is gallons you can collect!

example.title: Roof 30ft × 40ft, with 1 inch of rain:
example.steps:
Area: 30 × 40 = 1,200 sq ft
Gallons: 1,200 × 1 × 0.623 = 748 gallons
After 20% loss: 748 × 0.80 = 598 gallons!

sections.heading: Tip
sections.tip: 1 inch of rain on a 1,000 sq ft roof = about 600 gallons! Always filter and purify rainwater before drinking.

sections.heading: What This Calculates
sections.content: This helps you figure out how many watts of solar panels you need to power your devices.

sections.heading: The Formula
sections.formula: Panel Watts = (Daily Watt-hours needed) ÷ (Sun Hours × 0.8 efficiency)

sections.heading: Step-by-Step on Paper
steps: List each device and its watts (look on the label)
Write how many hours per day you use each device
Multiply watts × hours for each device = watt-hours
Add all watt-hours together = daily watt-hours
Find your sun hours (usually 4-6 hours)
Divide daily watt-hours by (sun hours × 0.8)
This is the watts of solar panels you need

example.title: LED light (10W for 6 hours) + Radio (5W for 4 hours), 5 sun hours:
example.steps:
LED: 10 × 6 = 60 Wh
Radio: 5 × 4 = 20 Wh
Total: 80 Wh per day
Panels needed: 80 ÷ (5 × 0.8) = 80 ÷ 4 = 20 watts of solar panels

battery-bank-sizing.title: How to Size a Battery Bank

sections.heading: What This Calculates
sections.content: This tells you how big your batteries need to be to store enough power for your needs.

sections.heading: The Formula
sections.formula: Battery Amp-hours = (Daily Wh) ÷ Battery Voltage ÷ Depth of Discharge × Days of Backup

sections.heading: Step-by-Step on Paper
steps: Calculate your daily watt-hours needed
Choose how many days of backup you want (usually 1-3)
Multiply daily Wh × backup days
Divide by battery voltage (usually 12V)
Divide by 0.5 (to not damage batteries, only use half)
This is your Amp-hour rating needed

example.title: 500 Wh per day, 2 days backup, 12V battery:
example.steps:
Total Wh: 500 × 2 = 1000 Wh
Basic Ah: 1000 ÷ 12 = 83 Ah
With 50% depth: 83 ÷ 0.5 = 166 Ah battery needed

sections.heading: What This Calculates
sections.content: This adds up all your electrical devices to find how much power you use per day in watt-hours.

sections.heading: The Formula
sections.formula: Daily Watt-hours = (Watts × Hours × Quantity) for each device, then add them all

sections.heading: Step-by-Step on Paper
steps: Make a list of every electrical device you use
Find the watts for each (look on the label or charger)
Estimate hours used per day for each
For each device: Watts × Hours × Quantity = Watt-hours
Add all the watt-hours together
This is your daily energy use!

sections.heading: Tip
sections.tip: Watts = how powerful something is. Watt-hours = how much energy it uses over time. Like a faucet (watts) vs total water used (watt-hours)!

sections.heading: What This Calculates
sections.content: This predicts how a group of people (or animals) will grow over time based on birth and death rates.

sections.heading: The Formula
sections.formula:
Future Pop = Current Pop × (1 + Growth Rate)^Years
Growth Rate = (Births - Deaths) ÷ Population

sections.heading: Step-by-Step on Paper
steps: Start with current population count
Calculate growth rate: (births per year - deaths per year) ÷ population
Convert to decimal (2% = 0.02)
Add 1 to growth rate (0.02 becomes 1.02)
Raise to power of years (multiply by itself that many times)
Multiply by current population

example.title: Community of 100 people, 3% annual growth, in 10 years:
example.steps:
Growth rate: 1 + 0.03 = 1.03
1.03^10 = 1.344 (multiply 1.03 by itself 10 times)
100 × 1.344 = 134 people

sections.heading: What This Calculates
sections.content: This helps you figure out how many people you need for different jobs based on time and tasks.

sections.heading: The Formula
sections.formula: Workers Needed = (Total Work Hours) ÷ (Hours per Worker per Day × Days)

sections.heading: Step-by-Step on Paper
steps: Estimate total hours needed for the job
Decide how many hours each person can work per day
Decide how many days you have to complete it
Multiply: hours per person × days = hours per worker
Divide total hours by hours per worker
Round up - you can't have half a person!

example.title: Garden needs 200 hours of work, 8-hour days, 5 days to complete:
example.steps:
Hours per worker: 8 × 5 = 40 hours
Workers needed: 200 ÷ 40 = 5 workers

sections.heading: What This Calculates
sections.content: This tells you how much living space you need for a group of people to live comfortably or survive.

sections.heading: The Formula
sections.formula:
Minimum Space = People × Square Feet per Person
Emergency: 20 sq ft/person | Basic: 100 sq ft/person | Comfortable: 200+ sq ft/person

sections.heading: Step-by-Step on Paper
steps: Count total people needing shelter
Decide comfort level needed
For emergency/temp: 20 sq ft × people
For basic living: 100 sq ft × people
For comfortable: 200 sq ft × people
Add common areas (cooking, bathroom): +50 sq ft per person

example.title: Family of 6 needs basic shelter:
example.steps:
Living space: 6 × 100 = 600 sq ft
Common areas: 6 × 50 = 300 sq ft
Total: 600 + 300 = 900 sq ft minimum

land-requirements-calculator.title: How Much Land to Grow Food

sections.heading: What This Calculates
sections.content: This tells you how much garden or farm land you need to grow enough food for your family.

sections.heading: The Formula
sections.formula:
Garden Size = People × 200 sq ft (intensive) to 4000 sq ft (traditional)
Rule of thumb: 1/4 acre per person for self-sufficiency

sections.heading: Step-by-Step on Paper
steps: Count people to feed year-round
For intensive raised beds: 200 sq ft per person
For traditional row gardening: 1000 sq ft per person
For complete food independence: 4000 sq ft (1/10 acre) per person
Add 25% extra for paths and storage
Double if you want to preserve food for winter

example.title: Family of 4, traditional garden with preservation:
example.steps:
Base garden: 4 × 1000 = 4,000 sq ft
For preservation: 4,000 × 2 = 8,000 sq ft
With paths: 8,000 × 1.25 = 10,000 sq ft
That's about 1/4 acre!

sections.heading: What This Calculates
sections.content: This estimates how much food you can harvest from your garden based on what you plant.

sections.heading: The Formula
sections.formula:
Total Yield = Plants × Average Yield per Plant
Or: Row Feet × Yield per Foot

sections.heading: Step-by-Step on Paper
steps: Count your plants OR measure row feet
Look up average yield for your crop (see common yields below)
Multiply: plants × yield OR feet × yield per foot
Reduce by 20% for realistic first-year expectations
This is your expected harvest!

sections.heading: Common Yields
sections.content: Tomatoes: 10-15 lbs per plant | Potatoes: 5-10 lbs per plant | Beans: 1/2 lb per foot | Corn: 1-2 ears per stalk | Lettuce: 1 head per plant | Squash: 5-10 lbs per plant

example.title: 12 tomato plants, 20 feet of beans:
example.steps:
Tomatoes: 12 plants × 12 lbs = 144 lbs
Beans: 20 feet × 0.5 lb = 10 lbs
With 20% reduction: 144 × 0.8 = 115 lbs tomatoes

sections.heading: What This Calculates
sections.content: This tells you how much food your animals need per day and per year.

sections.heading: The Formula
sections.formula:
Daily Feed = Animal Weight × Feed Percentage
Chickens: 1/4 lb/day | Goats: 3-4% body weight | Pigs: 4% body weight

sections.heading: Step-by-Step on Paper
steps: Weigh or estimate your animal's weight
Find the feed percentage for that animal type
Multiply: weight × percentage = daily feed
For yearly needs: daily × 365 days
Add 10% for waste and spills

sections.heading: Common Daily Feed
sections.content: Laying hen: 1/4 lb | Meat rabbit: 1/4 lb | 100lb goat: 3-4 lbs | 200lb pig: 6-8 lbs | Dairy cow: 30-40 lbs

example.title: 10 laying hens for one year:
example.steps:
Daily: 10 × 0.25 lb = 2.5 lbs per day
Yearly: 2.5 × 365 = 912.5 lbs
With waste: 912.5 × 1.1 = 1,004 lbs of feed per year

sections.heading: What This Calculates
sections.content: This tells you how much cement, sand, and gravel you need to make a certain amount of concrete.

sections.heading: The Formula
sections.formula:
Standard Mix Ratio: 1 part Cement : 2 parts Sand : 3 parts Gravel
Cubic Feet of Concrete = Length × Width × Thickness (all in feet)

sections.heading: Step-by-Step on Paper
steps: Calculate volume needed: length × width × depth (in feet)
Add 10% for waste and spillage
For each cubic foot of concrete, you need about:
- Cement: 0.22 cubic feet (or 29 lbs)
- Sand: 0.44 cubic feet
- Gravel: 0.66 cubic feet
Multiply each by your total cubic feet

example.title: Slab 10ft × 10ft × 4 inches (0.33ft):
example.steps:
Volume: 10 × 10 × 0.33 = 33 cubic feet
With waste: 33 × 1.1 = 36 cu ft
Cement: 36 × 0.22 = 8 cu ft (about 580 lbs)
Sand: 36 × 0.44 = 16 cu ft
Gravel: 36 × 0.66 = 24 cu ft

sections.heading: What This Calculates
sections.content: This helps you figure out how many boards you need for a building project.

sections.heading: The Formula
sections.formula:
Board Feet = (Thickness × Width × Length) ÷ 144
Note: All measurements in inches, length can be in feet

sections.heading: Step-by-Step on Paper
steps: Measure thickness of board in inches
Measure width of board in inches
Measure length of board in feet
Multiply: thickness × width × length
Divide by 12 (if length in feet)
This equals board feet
Add 15% for waste from cuts

example.title: How many board feet in a 2×6×8 board?
example.steps:
Thickness: 2 inches (actual 1.5)
Width: 6 inches (actual 5.5)
Length: 8 feet
Board feet: (2 × 6 × 8) ÷ 12 = 8 board feet

sections.heading: Tip
sections.tip: Lumber is named by rough size but sold smaller (a 2×4 is actually 1.5×3.5 inches). Always measure actual boards!

sections.heading: What This Calculates
sections.content: This tells you how much concrete you need for a foundation footer or wall.

sections.heading: The Formula
sections.formula:
Volume = Length × Width × Depth
For walls: Perimeter × Thickness × Height

sections.heading: Step-by-Step on Paper
steps: Measure the perimeter of your foundation
Decide footer width (usually 2× wall thickness)
Decide footer depth (usually 8-12 inches)
Calculate: perimeter × width × depth
Convert to cubic yards: divide cubic feet by 27
Add 10% for waste

example.title: Footer for 24ft × 30ft building, 18in wide, 8in deep:
example.steps:
Perimeter: (24 + 30) × 2 = 108 linear feet
Width: 18in = 1.5 feet
Depth: 8in = 0.67 feet
Volume: 108 × 1.5 × 0.67 = 109 cubic feet
Cubic yards: 109 ÷ 27 = 4.0 yards
With waste: 4.4 cubic yards needed

sections.heading: What This Calculates
sections.content: This tells you how much fuel you'll need for a trip or how far you can go with the fuel you have.

sections.heading: The Formula
sections.formula:
Fuel Needed = Distance ÷ Miles per Gallon
Range = Gallons × Miles per Gallon

sections.heading: Step-by-Step on Paper
steps: Find your vehicle's MPG (check owner's manual or gas receipts)
Measure or map the distance to travel
Divide distance by MPG = gallons needed
Add 20% for safety margin and detours
To find range: multiply gallons in tank by MPG

example.title: 300-mile trip in truck getting 15 MPG:
example.steps:
Base fuel: 300 ÷ 15 = 20 gallons
With 20% safety: 20 × 1.2 = 24 gallons needed

sections.heading: Tip
sections.tip: Heavy loads, hills, and AC reduce MPG by 10-30%. Plan for worst case when fuel is scarce!

sections.heading: What This Calculates
sections.content: This tells you how much weight you can safely carry in a vehicle or on a person/animal.

sections.heading: The Formula
sections.formula:
Available Capacity = Max Weight - Vehicle Weight - Passengers
Person Carry Rule: Max 25-30% of body weight for long distances

sections.heading: Step-by-Step on Paper
steps: Find max vehicle weight rating (door sticker or manual)
Subtract empty vehicle weight
Subtract passenger weights
Remaining = cargo capacity
For backpacks: body weight × 0.25 = comfortable carry weight

example.title: Truck rated 6000 lbs, weighs 4500 lbs, 3 people (450 lbs):
example.steps:
Max: 6000 lbs
Minus truck: 6000 - 4500 = 1500 lbs
Minus people: 1500 - 450 = 1050 lbs cargo capacity

sections.heading: What This Calculates
sections.content: This helps you figure out how long a trip will take by foot, vehicle, or with a loaded cart.

sections.heading: The Formula
sections.formula:
Time = Distance ÷ Speed
Walking: 3 mph | Heavy pack: 2 mph | Bicycle: 10 mph | Car: varies

sections.heading: Step-by-Step on Paper
steps: Measure total distance in miles
Estimate realistic speed for your mode of travel
Divide distance by speed = hours
Add time for rest breaks (10 min per hour walking)
Add extra for terrain: +25% for hills, +50% for rough terrain

example.title: 15-mile hike with heavy pack over hilly terrain:
example.steps:
Base speed: 2 mph
Base time: 15 ÷ 2 = 7.5 hours
Rest breaks: 7.5 × (10/60) = 1.25 hours
Hilly terrain: 8.75 × 1.25 = 11 hours total

weight-based-dosage-calculator.title: How to Calculate Medicine Dosage by Weight

sections.heading: What This Calculates
sections.content: This helps you figure out the right amount of medicine based on body weight.

sections.heading: The Formula
sections.formula:
Dose = Weight (kg) × Dose per kg
To convert lbs to kg: divide by 2.2

sections.heading: Step-by-Step on Paper
steps: Weigh the person in pounds
Convert to kg: weight ÷ 2.2
Find the recommended dose per kg (from medicine label)
Multiply: kg × dose per kg = total dose
Check that dose is within safe range
Calculate doses per day and total needed

example.title: Ibuprofen for 66 lb child (10mg/kg):
example.steps:
Weight in kg: 66 ÷ 2.2 = 30 kg
Dose: 30 × 10mg = 300mg
Children's ibuprofen is 100mg/5ml
So give: 15ml (300 ÷ 100 × 5)

sections.heading: Tip
sections.tip: Always check medicine labels for maximum daily doses. When in doubt, use less and wait. Never guess on serious medications!

oral-rehydration-calculator.title: How to Make Oral Rehydration Solution

sections.heading: What This Calculates
sections.content: This tells you how to mix a life-saving drink for someone with severe diarrhea or dehydration.

sections.heading: The Formula
sections.formula:
ORS Recipe per Liter of Clean Water:
• 6 level teaspoons of Sugar
• 1/2 level teaspoon of Salt

sections.heading: Step-by-Step on Paper
steps: Boil water and let it cool (or use clean bottled water)
Measure exactly 1 liter (about 4 cups)
Add 6 level teaspoons of sugar (not heaping!)
Add 1/2 level teaspoon of salt
Stir until completely dissolved
Taste - should be less salty than tears
Give small sips frequently (not large gulps)

sections.heading: How Much to Give
sections.content:
Children under 2: 1/4 to 1/2 cup after each loose stool
Older children: 1/2 to 1 cup after each loose stool
Adults: As much as wanted, at least 3 liters per day

sections.heading: Tip
sections.tip: If no measuring spoons: use the 'finger scoop' method - a pinch of salt, a small fistful of sugar. Too much salt is dangerous - when in doubt, use less salt!

first-aid-supply-estimator.title: How to Stock First Aid Supplies

sections.heading: What This Calculates
sections.content: This helps you estimate how many first aid supplies you need based on group size and time.

sections.heading: The Formula
sections.formula:
Supplies = People × Months × Usage Factor
Usage Factor: 0.5 for low risk, 1.0 for moderate, 2.0 for high risk

sections.heading: Basic Kit Per Person Per Month
sections.content:
• 10 adhesive bandages
• 2 gauze pads (4×4)
• 1 roll gauze bandage
• 2 alcohol wipes
• 4 pain relievers
• 2 antibiotic ointment packets
• 1 pair gloves

sections.heading: Step-by-Step on Paper
steps: Count people in your group
Decide how many months to prepare for
Multiply basic kit amounts by people × months
Double quantities for high-risk activities
Add specialty items for known medical needs
Check expiration dates and rotate stock

example.title: 4 people for 6 months, moderate risk:
example.steps:
Bandages: 10 × 4 × 6 × 1.0 = 240 bandages
Gauze pads: 2 × 4 × 6 = 48 pads
Pain relievers: 4 × 4 × 6 = 96 tablets

radio-range-estimator.title: How Far Can a Radio Reach?

sections.heading: What This Calculates
sections.content: This estimates how far your two-way radio can communicate based on power and terrain.

sections.heading: The Formula
sections.formula:
Rough Range = √(Power in Watts) × Terrain Factor × 2 miles
Terrain: Open=1.0, Hills=0.5, Forest=0.3, Urban=0.2

sections.heading: Realistic Ranges
sections.content:
• FRS radios (0.5W): 0.5-2 miles
• GMRS radios (5W): 2-5 miles
• CB radios (4W): 4-10 miles
• Ham radio (50W): 10-50+ miles

sections.heading: Step-by-Step on Paper
steps: Find your radio's power in watts
Take the square root of watts
Multiply by terrain factor
Multiply by 2 for base range in miles
Height helps! Each 10 feet of elevation = +10% range

example.title: 5-watt GMRS radio in hilly terrain:
example.steps:
√5 = 2.24
2.24 × 0.5 (hills) × 2 = 2.24 miles
From hilltop (+30ft): 2.24 × 1.3 = 2.9 miles

antenna-length-calculator.title: How Long Should an Antenna Be?

sections.heading: What This Calculates
sections.content: Radio waves travel at specific wavelengths. Your antenna works best when it matches that wavelength.

sections.heading: The Formula
sections.formula:
Wavelength (feet) = 984 ÷ Frequency (MHz)
Half-wave antenna = 468 ÷ Frequency
Quarter-wave antenna = 234 ÷ Frequency

sections.heading: Step-by-Step on Paper
steps: Find your radio's frequency in MHz
For a half-wave dipole: divide 468 by frequency
For a quarter-wave: divide 234 by frequency
Result is length in feet
Multiply by 12 for inches

example.title: Quarter-wave antenna for 146 MHz ham radio:

sections.heading: Common Antenna Lengths
sections.content:
CB (27 MHz): 102 inches (quarter-wave)
FRS/GMRS (462 MHz): 6 inches
2m Ham (146 MHz): 19 inches
WiFi (2.4 GHz): 1.2 inches

line-of-sight-distance.title: How Far Can You See (Line of Sight)?

sections.heading: What This Calculates
sections.content: This tells you how far away the horizon is based on your height. Important for radio, signaling, and navigation.

sections.heading: The Formula
sections.formula:
Distance (miles) = 1.22 × √Height (feet)
Or: Distance (km) = 3.57 × √Height (meters)

sections.heading: Step-by-Step on Paper
steps: Measure your eye height in feet (standing = ~5.5 ft)
Add any elevation (hilltop, tower, etc.)
Take the square root of total height
Multiply by 1.22
This is distance to horizon in miles

sections.heading: Quick Reference
sections.content: Eye level (5.5 ft): 2.9 miles | 20 ft: 5.5 miles | 50 ft: 8.6 miles | 100 ft: 12.5 miles | 500 ft: 27 miles

sections.heading: What This Calculates
sections.content: Force is what makes things move or stop. This calculates how much push or pull you need.

sections.heading: The Formula
sections.formula:
Force (Newtons) = Mass (kg) × Acceleration (m/s²)
For weight: Force = Mass × 9.8 (gravity)

sections.heading: Step-by-Step on Paper
steps: Find the mass of the object in kg (divide lbs by 2.2)
Determine the acceleration (how fast it speeds up)
Multiply mass × acceleration = force in Newtons
To convert to pounds of force: divide Newtons by 4.45

example.title: How much force to accelerate a 50kg cart at 2 m/s²?
example.steps:
Force = 50 × 2 = 100 Newtons
In pounds: 100 ÷ 4.45 = 22.5 lbs of push

sections.heading: What This Calculates
sections.content: Ohm's Law shows how voltage, current, and resistance relate in electrical circuits.

sections.heading: The Formula
sections.formula:
V = I × R (Voltage = Current × Resistance)
I = V ÷ R (Current = Voltage ÷ Resistance)
R = V ÷ I (Resistance = Voltage ÷ Current)

sections.heading: What the Terms Mean
sections.content:
Voltage (V) = electrical pressure (measured in Volts)
Current (I) = flow of electricity (measured in Amps)
Resistance (R) = how hard it is for electricity to flow (measured in Ohms)

sections.heading: Step-by-Step on Paper
steps: Identify what you know (any two values)
Choose the right formula
Plug in your known values
Solve for the unknown

example.title: 12V battery, 2 Ohm resistance - how much current?
example.steps:
I = V ÷ R
I = 12 ÷ 2 = 6 Amps

sections.heading: Tip
sections.tip: Power (Watts) = Volts × Amps. A 12V battery providing 6 Amps delivers 72 Watts of power!

sections.heading: What This Calculates
sections.content: Energy is the ability to do work. These formulas help you calculate different types of energy.

sections.heading: The Formulas
sections.formula:
Kinetic Energy = ½ × mass × velocity²
Potential Energy = mass × gravity × height
Work = Force × Distance

sections.heading: Step-by-Step for Kinetic Energy
steps: Find the mass in kg
Find the velocity (speed) in m/s
Square the velocity (multiply by itself)
Multiply mass × velocity²
Divide by 2

example.title: Kinetic energy of 1000kg car going 20 m/s:

sections.heading: What This Calculates
sections.content: Pressure is force spread over an area. Used for tires, hydraulics, water tanks, and more.

sections.heading: The Formula
sections.formula:
Pressure = Force ÷ Area
Water pressure (PSI) = Height (feet) × 0.433

sections.heading: Step-by-Step on Paper
steps: Find the force in pounds
Find the area in square inches
Divide force by area = PSI (pounds per square inch)
For water: multiply height in feet by 0.433

example.title: Water tank 50 feet tall - what pressure at bottom?
example.steps: Pressure = 50 × 0.433 = 21.65 PSI

sections.heading: Common Pressures
sections.content: Car tire: 30-35 PSI | Bicycle tire: 80-130 PSI | House water: 40-80 PSI | Scuba tank: 3000 PSI

sections.heading: What This Calculates
sections.content: Convert between different units of measurement for length, weight, volume, and temperature.

sections.heading: Length Conversions
sections.formula:
1 inch = 2.54 cm
1 foot = 0.3048 m
1 mile = 1.609 km
1 meter = 3.28 feet

sections.heading: Weight Conversions
sections.formula:
1 pound = 0.454 kg
1 kg = 2.205 lbs
1 ounce = 28.35 grams
1 ton = 2000 lbs = 907 kg

sections.heading: Volume Conversions
sections.formula:
1 gallon = 3.785 liters
1 liter = 0.264 gallons
1 cup = 236 ml
1 tablespoon = 15 ml

sections.heading: What This Calculates
sections.content: Percentages help you find parts of a whole, like 'what is 20% of 150?' or '15 is what percent of 60?'

sections.heading: The Formulas
sections.formula:
X% of Y = (X ÷ 100) × Y
X is what % of Y = (X ÷ Y) × 100
% Change = ((New - Old) ÷ Old) × 100

sections.heading: Step-by-Step on Paper
steps: For 'X% of Y': Divide X by 100, then multiply by Y
For 'X is what % of Y': Divide X by Y, then multiply by 100
For '% change': Subtract old from new, divide by old, multiply by 100

ratio-proportion.title: How to Solve Ratios and Proportions

sections.heading: What This Calculates
sections.content: Ratios compare two amounts. Proportions help you scale things up or down while keeping the same relationship.

sections.heading: The Formula
sections.formula:
If A:B = C:D, then A × D = B × C
To find unknown: X = (A × D) ÷ B

sections.heading: Step-by-Step on Paper
steps: Write out what you know as a proportion: A/B = C/D
Cross multiply: A × D = B × C
Solve for the unknown by dividing

example.title: Recipe calls for 2 cups flour for 24 cookies. How much for 36 cookies?

sections.heading: What This Calculates
sections.content: This shows how money grows over time when you earn interest on your interest. It's like a snowball getting bigger!

sections.heading: The Formula
sections.formula:
Final Amount = Principal × (1 + Rate/n)^(n×Years)
Where n = times compounded per year

sections.heading: Step-by-Step on Paper
steps: Write your starting amount (Principal)
Convert interest rate to decimal (5% = 0.05)
Divide rate by times compounded (yearly=1, monthly=12)
Add 1 to that number
Multiply years × times compounded
Raise step 4 to the power of step 5
Multiply Principal by that result

sections.heading: What This Calculates
sections.content: Inflation makes money worth less over time. This calculates what past money is worth today, or what today's money will be worth later.

sections.heading: The Formula
sections.formula:
Future Value = Present Value × (1 + Inflation Rate)^Years
Past Value = Today's Value ÷ (1 + Inflation Rate)^Years

sections.heading: Step-by-Step on Paper
steps: Find the inflation rate (historically ~3% per year)
Convert to decimal (3% = 0.03)
Add 1 (becomes 1.03)
Raise to power of years
Multiply or divide your value

example.title: What will $100 be worth in 10 years at 3% inflation?

sections.heading: What This Calculates
sections.content: In barter (trading without money), value depends on need, scarcity, and usefulness. This helps you estimate fair trades.

sections.heading: The Formula
sections.formula:
Barter Value = (Utility × Scarcity × Demand) ÷ Availability
Score each factor 1-10

sections.heading: Value Factors
steps: Utility: How useful is it? (water=10, decorations=1)
Scarcity: How rare is it? (medicine=10, dirt=1)
Demand: How many people want it? (food=10, luxury=2)
Availability: How easy to get? (common=10, rare=1)
Higher score = more valuable

sections.heading: High-Value Barter Items
sections.content: Water purification | Seeds | Medicine | Ammunition | Tools | Fuel | Salt | Alcohol | Batteries | Skills/Labor

sections.heading: Tip
sections.tip: Fair trade means both people feel they gained something. Value changes based on situation - water is worth more in a desert!

sections.heading: What This Calculates
sections.content: This helps you figure out fair pay for work or how long a job will take multiple people.

sections.heading: The Formula
sections.formula:
Total Labor Hours = People × Hours per Person
Value = Hours × Rate per Hour

sections.heading: Step-by-Step on Paper
steps: Estimate total hours needed for the job
Decide how many people will work
Divide: total hours ÷ workers = hours per person
Multiply hours × agreed rate = value

example.title: Building a fence takes 40 hours, 2 workers:
example.steps:
40 ÷ 2 = 20 hours each
If rate is 3 lbs of grain per hour:
20 × 3 = 60 lbs of grain per worker

sections.heading: What This Calculates
sections.content: Two-stroke engines (chainsaws, weed eaters, small outboards) need oil mixed with gas. Wrong mix can destroy the engine!

sections.heading: The Formula
sections.formula:
Oil (oz) = Gas (gallons) × 128 ÷ Ratio
Common ratios: 50:1, 40:1, 32:1

sections.heading: Step-by-Step on Paper
steps: Check your engine's required ratio (usually on cap or manual)
Decide how much gas you need in gallons
Multiply gallons × 128 (ounces per gallon)
Divide by the ratio number
Result is ounces of oil to add

example.title: 1 gallon of gas at 50:1 ratio:
example.steps:
1 × 128 = 128 ounces of gas
128 ÷ 50 = 2.56 ounces of oil
About 2.5 oz (5 tablespoons) of 2-stroke oil

sections.heading: Quick Reference
sections.content: 50:1 = 2.6 oz per gallon | 40:1 = 3.2 oz per gallon | 32:1 = 4 oz per gallon

sections.heading: What This Calculates
sections.content: Gears trade speed for power. This tells you how much faster or stronger a machine gets with different gear sizes.

sections.heading: The Formula
sections.formula:
Gear Ratio = Driven Gear Teeth ÷ Drive Gear Teeth
Output RPM = Input RPM ÷ Gear Ratio

sections.heading: Step-by-Step on Paper
steps: Count teeth on the driving gear (the one connected to the motor)
Count teeth on the driven gear (the one doing the work)
Divide driven teeth by drive teeth = gear ratio
If ratio > 1: more power, less speed
If ratio < 1: more speed, less power
To find output speed: divide input RPM by gear ratio

example.title: Drive gear has 20 teeth, driven gear has 60 teeth:
example.steps:
Ratio: 60 ÷ 20 = 3:1
This means 3× more torque (power), 3× slower speed
If motor spins 900 RPM: 900 ÷ 3 = 300 RPM output

sections.heading: What This Calculates
sections.content: Your speedometer uses tire rotations to measure speed. Different tire sizes change your actual speed vs displayed speed.

sections.heading: The Formula
sections.formula:
Actual Speed = Displayed Speed × (New Tire Diameter ÷ Old Tire Diameter)
Tire Diameter = (Width × Aspect ÷ 2540) + Rim Diameter

sections.heading: Step-by-Step on Paper
steps: Find tire size (like 265/70R17)
Width = 265mm, Aspect = 70%, Rim = 17 inches
Sidewall height = 265 × 0.70 = 185.5mm = 7.3 inches
Diameter = (7.3 × 2) + 17 = 31.6 inches
Compare to original tire diameter

example.title: Stock 245/75R16 vs new 285/75R16:
example.steps:
Stock diameter: 30.5 inches
New diameter: 32.8 inches
At 60 mph displayed: 60 × (32.8÷30.5) = 64.5 mph actual

sections.heading: What This Calculates
sections.content: Salt curing preserves meat without refrigeration. This tells you how much salt you need for safe preservation.

sections.heading: The Formula
sections.formula:
Salt Needed = Meat Weight × 0.03 to 0.04 (3-4%)
Curing Time = 1-2 days per pound of meat

sections.heading: Step-by-Step on Paper
steps: Weigh your meat in pounds
Multiply by 0.03 for light cure or 0.04 for heavy cure
Result is pounds of salt needed
For each pound of meat, cure 1-2 days
Keep meat cold (below 40°F) during cure

example.title: 10 lb pork belly for bacon:
example.steps:
Salt: 10 × 0.035 = 0.35 lbs (about 5.6 oz)
Add 1 oz sugar, 0.1 oz curing salt (#1)
Cure time: 10-14 days in refrigerator

sections.heading: Tip
sections.tip: For safety, use curing salt (#1 or #2) which contains nitrite. Regular salt alone doesn't prevent botulism in wet cures!

canning-pressure-time.title: How to Calculate Canning Pressure & Time

sections.heading: What This Calculates
sections.content: Pressure canning is required for low-acid foods (meat, vegetables) to kill dangerous bacteria. This ensures safe preservation.

sections.heading: The Rules
sections.formula:
Low-acid foods: 10-15 PSI for 20-90 minutes
Adjust for altitude: +0.5 PSI per 1000 feet above sea level

sections.heading: Safe Canning Times (at 10 PSI)
sections.content: Chicken/meat: 75-90 minutes | Fish: 100 minutes | Vegetables: 20-40 minutes | Beans: 75 minutes | Stock/broth: 20-25 minutes

sections.heading: Step-by-Step on Paper
steps: Determine your altitude above sea level
Look up base processing time for your food
For dial gauge: add 0.5 PSI per 1000 ft
For weighted gauge: use 15 lbs above 1000 ft
Never reduce time - only increase for larger jars

example.title: Canning chicken at 3000 ft elevation:
example.steps:
Base: 10 PSI, 75 minutes for quarts
Altitude adjustment: +1.5 PSI
Use 11.5 PSI for 75 minutes

sections.heading: Tip
sections.tip: Never can dairy, flour, or dense purées. Always use tested recipes from USDA or Ball. When in doubt, throw it out!

bread-dough-calculator.title: How to Calculate Bread Dough (Baker's Percentage)

sections.heading: What This Calculates
sections.content: Bakers measure ingredients as a percentage of flour weight. This helps you scale recipes up or down perfectly!

sections.heading: The Formula
sections.formula:
Ingredient Amount = Flour Weight × (Ingredient % ÷ 100)
Common: Flour=100%, Water=60-75%, Salt=2%, Yeast=1%

sections.heading: Step-by-Step on Paper
steps: Start with your flour weight (this is always 100%)
For water at 65%: multiply flour × 0.65
For salt at 2%: multiply flour × 0.02
For yeast at 1%: multiply flour × 0.01
Add all weights together for total dough weight

sections.heading: What This Calculates
sections.content: This tells you how much water your well can produce per hour or day, and if it can meet your needs.

sections.heading: The Formula
sections.formula:
Output (GPH) = Gallons Pumped ÷ Time (hours)
Recovery Rate = Time for water level to return after pumping

sections.heading: Step-by-Step to Test
steps: Pump well until water level drops significantly
Note how many gallons pumped and time taken
Stop pumping and time how long to recover
Gallons ÷ hours = gallons per hour
For daily output: GPH × hours you can pump
Allow time for recharge (usually pump max 4-6 hrs/day)

example.title: Well pumps 200 gallons in 30 minutes before slowing:
example.steps:
GPH: 200 ÷ 0.5 = 400 gallons per hour
If recovery takes 2 hours, pump 30min every 2.5 hours
Daily: ~8 cycles × 200 gal = 1600 gallons/day

pipe-flow-calculator.title: How Much Water Flows Through a Pipe

sections.heading: What This Calculates
sections.content: This tells you how much water can flow through a pipe based on size and pressure.

sections.heading: The Formula (Simplified)
sections.formula:
Flow (GPM) ≈ 28.5 × Diameter² × √Pressure
Diameter in inches, Pressure in PSI

sections.heading: Step-by-Step on Paper
steps: Measure pipe inner diameter in inches
Square the diameter (multiply by itself)
Find your water pressure (typically 40-60 PSI)
Take square root of pressure
Multiply: 28.5 × diameter² × √pressure

example.title: 3/4 inch pipe at 50 PSI:
example.steps:
Diameter²: 0.75² = 0.5625
√50 = 7.07
Flow: 28.5 × 0.5625 × 7.07 = 113 GPM theoretical
Practical with friction: ~15-20 GPM

sections.heading: Pipe Capacity Quick Reference
sections.content: 1/2 inch: 5-8 GPM | 3/4 inch: 12-20 GPM | 1 inch: 20-30 GPM | 1.5 inch: 40-60 GPM | 2 inch: 70-100 GPM

septic-tank-sizing.title: How to Size a Septic Tank

sections.heading: What This Calculates
sections.content: This tells you how big your septic tank needs to be based on household size and water use.

sections.heading: The Formula
sections.formula:
Tank Size (gallons) = People × Daily Use × Retention Days
Minimum = 1000 gallons for most homes

sections.heading: Step-by-Step on Paper
steps: Count people in household
Estimate daily water use (50-75 gallons per person)
Multiply people × daily use
Multiply by 2-3 days retention time
Add 50% for solid storage
Round up to standard tank size

example.title: 4-person household, average water use:
example.steps:
Daily: 4 × 60 = 240 gallons/day
Retention: 240 × 2.5 = 600 gallons
With solids: 600 × 1.5 = 900 gallons
Use: 1000 gallon tank (minimum)

sections.heading: Standard Sizes
sections.content: 1-2 bedroom: 750-1000 gal | 3 bedroom: 1000 gal | 4 bedroom: 1250 gal | 5 bedroom: 1500 gal

roof-load-calculator.title: How Much Weight Can a Roof Hold?

sections.heading: What This Calculates
sections.content: This tells you how much snow or other weight your roof can safely support.

sections.heading: The Formula
sections.formula:
Snow Load (PSF) = Snow Depth (inches) × Snow Density
Wet snow: 20 lbs per inch | Dry snow: 5-10 lbs per inch
Typical roof: designed for 20-40 PSF total load

sections.heading: Step-by-Step on Paper
steps: Measure snow depth on roof in inches
Estimate density (fresh=5, packed=10, wet=15-20 lbs/inch)
Multiply: depth × density = PSF load
Compare to roof rating (usually 20-40 PSF)
If over 50% of rating, consider removing snow

example.title: 24 inches of packed snow on 30 PSF rated roof:
example.steps:
Load: 24 × 10 = 240 lbs per sq ft total
But snow compacts, so realistically: ~18-20 PSF
Still 60% of rating - monitor closely!

sections.heading: Tip
sections.tip: Roof collapses often happen during thaw - wet snow is 3-4× heavier than dry! Remove snow if it starts to rain on snow.

sections.heading: What This Calculates
sections.content: This tells you if a wooden beam is strong enough for the weight you want to put on it.

sections.heading: The Formula (Simplified)
sections.formula:
Max Load = (4 × Fb × Section Modulus) ÷ Span
Section Modulus = Width × Height² ÷ 6

sections.heading: Step-by-Step on Paper
steps: Measure beam: width (b) and height (d) in inches
Calculate Section Modulus: b × d² ÷ 6
Find Fb (allowable stress) for your wood (~1000-1500 PSI for common lumber)
Multiply: 4 × Fb × Section Modulus
Divide by span length in inches
Result is max center load in pounds

example.title: 2×10 beam spanning 8 feet, Fb=1000 PSI:
example.steps:
Section Modulus: 1.5 × 9.25² ÷ 6 = 21.4 in³
4 × 1000 × 21.4 = 85,600
85,600 ÷ 96 inches = 891 lbs max center load

sections.heading: Tip
sections.tip: Use safety factor of 2-3 for any structure. If math says 900 lbs, don't put more than 300-450 lbs on it!

rope-cable-safe-load.title: How to Calculate Rope Safe Working Load

sections.heading: What This Calculates
sections.content: Rope can hold a lot, but you should only use a fraction of its strength to be safe. This calculates how much you can safely lift.

sections.heading: The Formula
sections.formula:
Safe Working Load = Breaking Strength ÷ Safety Factor
Safety Factor: 5 for lifting people, 4 for general use

sections.heading: Common Rope Strengths
sections.content: 1/4 inch Manila: 540 lbs | 1/2 inch Manila: 2380 lbs | 1/4 inch Nylon: 1490 lbs | 1/2 inch Nylon: 5750 lbs | Paracord 550: 550 lbs

sections.heading: Step-by-Step on Paper
steps: Find rope's breaking strength (on package or chart)
Choose safety factor (5 for people, 4 for cargo)
Divide: breaking strength ÷ safety factor
Reduce by 50% if using knots!
Result is safe working load

example.title: 1/2 inch nylon rope for lifting gear:
example.steps:
Breaking: 5750 lbs
SWL: 5750 ÷ 4 = 1438 lbs
With knots: 1438 × 0.5 = 719 lbs max safe load

insulation-calculator.title: How Much Insulation Do You Need?

sections.heading: What This Calculates
sections.content: Insulation is measured in R-value (resistance to heat flow). This helps you figure out how much you need.

sections.heading: The Formula
sections.formula:
Total R-Value = Sum of all layer R-values
Heat Loss = (Area × Temperature Difference) ÷ R-value

sections.heading: Recommended R-Values
sections.content: Attic: R-38 to R-60 | Walls: R-13 to R-21 | Floors: R-25 to R-30 | Basement: R-10 to R-15

sections.heading: Step-by-Step on Paper
steps: Find recommended R-value for your climate zone
Check R-value per inch of your insulation type
Divide needed R-value by R per inch = thickness needed
Measure area to cover in square feet
Add 10% for waste and gaps

example.title: Need R-38 in attic using fiberglass batts (R-3.2/inch):
example.steps:
Thickness: 38 ÷ 3.2 = 12 inches needed
Attic area: 1000 sq ft
Batts at 15 in wide: 1000 ÷ 1.25 = 800 linear feet
With waste: 880 linear feet of batts

sections.heading: What This Calculates
sections.content: Wind makes cold air feel even colder. This tells you what temperature it 'feels like' when the wind is blowing.

sections.heading: The Formula (NWS)
sections.formula:
Wind Chill = 35.74 + 0.6215T - 35.75V^0.16 + 0.4275T × V^0.16
T = temperature (°F), V = wind speed (mph)

sections.heading: Simple Estimation
steps: For every 5 mph of wind, it feels about 3°F colder
At 10°F with 20mph wind: feels like about -10°F
Below 0°F wind chill: risk of frostbite in 30 minutes
Below -20°F wind chill: frostbite in 10 minutes!

sections.heading: Tip
sections.tip: Always check wind chill before going outside in winter. Cover all exposed skin when wind chill is below 0°F!

sections.heading: What This Calculates
sections.content: Humidity makes hot air feel even hotter. This tells you the 'feels like' temperature on humid days.

sections.heading: Simple Estimation
steps: At 90°F with 50% humidity: feels like 95°F
At 90°F with 80% humidity: feels like 113°F!
Above 105°F heat index: danger zone
Above 130°F heat index: extreme danger

sections.heading: Stay Safe
sections.content: 80-90°F index: Caution | 90-105°F: Extreme caution | 105-130°F: Danger | 130°F+: Extreme danger

sections.heading: Tip
sections.tip: When heat index is high: drink lots of water, stay in shade, avoid heavy work during midday, watch for heat exhaustion signs.

sections.heading: What This Calculates
sections.content: Dew point is the temperature where moisture in the air condenses into water droplets. Important for fog, frost, and comfort.

sections.heading: The Formula (Approximate)
sections.formula:
Dew Point ≈ Temperature - ((100 - Humidity) ÷ 5)
This works for humidity above 50%

sections.heading: Step-by-Step on Paper
steps: Get current temperature in °F
Get current humidity percentage
Subtract humidity from 100
Divide by 5
Subtract from temperature = approximate dew point

sections.heading: What Dew Point Tells You
sections.content: Below 55°F: comfortable | 55-65°F: sticky | 65-70°F: muggy | Above 70°F: oppressive | Above 75°F: dangerous

sections.heading: What This Calculates
sections.content: Knowing where the sun is helps with solar panel placement, telling time, and navigation.

sections.heading: Simple Methods
steps: Sun rises in the East, sets in the West
At noon, sun is due South (in Northern Hemisphere)
Sun is highest in sky at solar noon
Solar noon ≈ 12:00 - (timezone offset × 15°) + (longitude difference)
Sun angle at noon = 90° - latitude + declination

sections.heading: Shadow Method
sections.content: Stick shadow shortest at solar noon | Shadow points North at noon (N. Hemisphere) | Shadow length ratio tells sun angle

sections.heading: Seasonal Changes
sections.content: Summer: Sun rises NE, sets NW, high in sky | Winter: Sun rises SE, sets SW, low in sky | Equinox: Sun rises due E, sets due W

sections.heading: What This Calculates
sections.content: This tells you how to make a weaker solution from a stronger one by adding water.

sections.heading: The Formula
sections.formula:
C1 × V1 = C2 × V2
C1 = starting concentration | V1 = starting volume
C2 = final concentration | V2 = final volume

sections.heading: Step-by-Step on Paper
steps: Identify what you know (usually C1, C2, and desired V2)
Plug into formula: V1 = (C2 × V2) ÷ C1
This tells you how much of the concentrate to use
Add water to reach final volume

example.title: Make 1 liter of 10% bleach from 50% bleach:

sections.heading: What This Calculates
sections.content: pH measures how acidic or alkaline (basic) a solution is. Scale goes 0-14, with 7 being neutral.

sections.heading: The Scale
sections.formula:
pH = -log[H+]
0-6 = Acid | 7 = Neutral | 8-14 = Base (Alkaline)
Each number is 10× stronger than the next

sections.heading: Common pH Values
sections.content: Battery acid: 0 | Lemon juice: 2 | Vinegar: 3 | Tomatoes: 4 | Coffee: 5 | Milk: 6.5 | Water: 7 | Baking soda: 8 | Soap: 10 | Bleach: 12 | Drain cleaner: 14

sections.heading: Important for Survival
steps: Drinking water: should be pH 6.5-8.5
Soil for gardening: most plants like pH 6-7
Food preservation: acid foods (below pH 4.6) are safer
Swimming pool: pH 7.2-7.8

sections.heading: What This Calculates
sections.content: Gravity pulls bullets down as they fly. This helps estimate how much to aim above a distant target.

sections.heading: The Formula (Simplified)
sections.formula:
Drop (inches) = (Distance² × 193) ÷ (Velocity²)
Distance in yards, Velocity in feet per second

sections.heading: General Rules
steps: Bullets drop increasingly more at longer ranges
Faster bullets drop less
At 100 yards: typical rifle drops 1-3 inches
At 300 yards: typical rifle drops 10-20 inches
Wind also pushes bullets sideways

sections.heading: Tip
sections.tip: Every gun and load is different. Use manufacturer's ballistic data or test at a range. This is only for rough estimation!

sections.heading: What This Calculates
sections.content: This tells you how many sandbags you need to build a protective wall of a certain size.

sections.heading: The Formula
sections.formula:
Bags = (Length × Height × Thickness) ÷ 0.5 cubic feet
A filled sandbag is about 14×6×4 inches (0.5 cu ft)

sections.heading: Step-by-Step on Paper
steps: Measure wall length in feet
Decide wall height in feet
Choose thickness (1, 2, or 3 bags deep)
Bags per row: length × 1.5 (bags overlap)
Number of layers: height × 2 (bags are 6 inches high)
Multiply: rows × layers × thickness
Add 10% extra for waste

example.title: 10ft wall, 3ft high, 2 bags thick:
example.steps:
Bags per row: 10 × 1.5 = 15 bags
Layers: 3 × 2 = 6 layers
Total: 15 × 6 × 2 = 180 bags
With 10% extra: 198 bags needed

sections.heading: What This Calculates
sections.content: This helps you figure out how many people you need to patrol an area 24 hours a day.

sections.heading: The Formula
sections.formula:
People Needed = (Hours to Cover × Posts) ÷ (Hours per Shift) × Coverage Factor
Coverage Factor: 1.5 for sustainable, 2.0 for long-term

sections.heading: Step-by-Step on Paper
steps: Count observation posts needed
Decide hours per shift (4-8 hours typical)
Calculate shifts per day: 24 ÷ shift length
Multiply: posts × shifts = total shift-slots
Multiply by coverage factor (for days off, sickness)
This is minimum people needed

example.title: 4 watch posts, 8-hour shifts, sustainable schedule:
example.steps:
Shifts per day: 24 ÷ 8 = 3 shifts
Slots: 4 posts × 3 = 12 shift-slots per day
With coverage: 12 × 1.5 = 18 people minimum

wind-turbine-power.title: How Much Power from a Wind Turbine?

sections.heading: What This Calculates
sections.content: Wind turbines convert wind energy to electricity. Power increases dramatically with wind speed!

sections.heading: The Formula
sections.formula:
Power (watts) = 0.5 × Air Density × Area × Velocity³ × Efficiency
Simplified: Power ≈ 0.01 × Diameter² × WindSpeed³

sections.heading: Key Concept
sections.content:
Doubling wind speed = 8× more power! (because speed is cubed)
10 mph wind → X power | 20 mph wind → 8X power

sections.heading: Step-by-Step on Paper
steps: Measure or estimate blade diameter in feet
Square the diameter
Find average wind speed in mph
Cube the wind speed (multiply by itself 3 times)
Multiply: 0.01 × diameter² × speed³
Result is approximate watts

example.title: 6-foot diameter turbine in 15 mph wind:
example.steps:
Diameter²: 6² = 36
Wind³: 15³ = 3375
Power: 0.01 × 36 × 3375 = 1215 watts peak

water-wheel-turbine-power.title: How Much Power from a Water Wheel?

sections.heading: What This Calculates
sections.content: Flowing water can generate electricity. Power depends on how much water and how far it falls.

sections.heading: The Formula
sections.formula:
Power (watts) = Flow (GPM) × Head (feet) × 0.18 × Efficiency
Efficiency typically 50-70% for small systems

sections.heading: Step-by-Step on Paper
steps: Measure water flow in gallons per minute
Measure vertical drop (head) in feet
Multiply: flow × head × 0.18
Multiply by efficiency (0.5 to 0.7)
Result is watts of power

example.title: Stream with 100 GPM flow, 10 feet of drop:
example.steps:
Basic: 100 × 10 × 0.18 = 180 watts potential
At 60% efficiency: 180 × 0.6 = 108 watts actual

sections.heading: Tip
sections.tip: Head (drop) is more important than flow. A small amount of water falling far produces more than lots of water with small drop.

wire-gauge-calculator.title: What Wire Size Do You Need?

sections.heading: What This Calculates
sections.content: Too-thin wire gets hot and wastes power. This tells you what gauge wire to use for your electrical project.

sections.heading: The Formula
sections.formula:
Circular Mils = (Amps × Distance × 2 × 12.9) ÷ Voltage Drop
Then look up wire gauge from circular mil rating

sections.heading: Quick Reference (Copper, 12V)
sections.content: 5 Amps, 10ft: 18 AWG | 10 Amps, 10ft: 14 AWG | 15 Amps, 10ft: 12 AWG | 20 Amps, 10ft: 10 AWG | 30 Amps, 10ft: 8 AWG

sections.heading: Rules of Thumb
steps: Lower gauge number = thicker wire
Double the distance = need 3 gauge sizes larger
Double the amps = need 3 gauge sizes larger
12V systems need much thicker wire than 120V
When in doubt, go one size larger

example.title: 10 amp load, 20 feet from battery at 12V:
example.steps:
At 10ft, 10A needs 14 AWG
Double distance: need 3 sizes larger
Use 10 AWG wire (or 8 AWG to be safe)

sections.heading: What This Contains
sections.content: Common conversions and reference values for quick lookup during calculations.

sections.heading: Temperature
sections.formula:
Water freezes: 32°F / 0°C
Body temperature: 98.6°F / 37°C
Water boils: 212°F / 100°C

sections.heading: Weight
sections.content:
1 pound = 16 ounces = 454 grams
1 kilogram = 2.2 pounds
1 ton = 2000 pounds

sections.heading: Volume
sections.content:
1 gallon = 4 quarts = 8 pints = 128 oz = 3.785 liters
1 cup = 8 oz = 236 ml
1 tablespoon = 3 teaspoons = 15 ml

sections.heading: Length
sections.content:
1 foot = 12 inches = 30.48 cm
1 yard = 3 feet = 0.914 m
1 mile = 5,280 feet = 1.609 km
